    <item>
      <title>Pain Spreads as Credit Vise Grows Tighter</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/economy/19econ.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/economy/19econ.html</guid>
      <media:group>
        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/business/19econ01-75.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>A shopper browsing at a Harley-Davidson dealership in Texas. Harley-Davidson is now issuing bonds at slightly higher rates.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Brian Harkin for The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>Lenders have become even less willing to part with their money, further crimping budgets and family spending.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By LOUIS UCHITELLE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 12:43:45 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Credit</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">United States Economy</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Economic Conditions and Trends</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Finances</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">American Bankers Assn</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>For Rivals, Finance Crisis Is Posing on-the-Fly Tests</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19campaign.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19campaign.html</guid>
      <media:group>
        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/us/19campaign.75.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Barack Obama on Thursday in Bernalillo, N.M. He and his rival, John McCain, are expected to discuss economic details soon.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Damon Winter/The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>The presidential race has turned into an audition for who could best handle a national economic emergency.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By JACKIE CALMES and JEFF ZELENY</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 11:44:12 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Presidential Election of 2008</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">United States Economy</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">McCain, John</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Obama, Barack</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Securities and Exchange Commission</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Cox, Christopher</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Paulson, Henry M Jr</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Bernanke, Ben S</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Drug Label, Maimed Patient and Test for Court</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19scotus.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19scotus.html</guid>
      <media:group>
        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/us/19scotus_75a.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Diana Levine lost part of an arm after being given a drug. A jury ordered Wyeth, a pharmaceutical company, to pay $6 million.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>At issue is whether plaintiffs have the right to sue when the products that hurt them had met federal standards.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By ADAM LIPTAK</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 12:39:18 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Supreme Court</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Suits and Litigation</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Decisions and Verdicts</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Wyeth|WYE|NYSE</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Food and Drug Administration</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Vermont</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>After Impasse, New California Budget Agreement</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19calif.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19calif.html</guid>
      <description>California legislative leaders and the governor have come to an agreement on the state budget, which is now roughly three months late.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By JENNIFER STEINHAUER</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 08:20:47 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">California</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Budgets and Budgeting</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Schwarzenegger, Arnold</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>California Bans Texting by Operators of Trains</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19crash.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19crash.html</guid>
      <description>After investigators said an engineer in last week’s collision had been texting on the job, regulators temporarily banned the use of all cellular devices by anyone at the controls of a moving train.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By JESSE McKINLEY and MATTHEW L. WALD</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 07:01:46 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Accidents and Safety</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Railroads</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Text Messaging</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">California Public Utilities Commission</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Transit Systems</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Cellular Telephones</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Metrolink (Southern California Regional Rail Authority)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Sanchez, Robert M</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">California</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Los Angeles (Calif)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Political Memo: Given G.O.P. Predicament, Rangel Opts to Ride Out the Storm</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/washington/19memo.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/washington/19memo.html</guid>
      <media:group>
        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/us/19memo_75.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Representative Charles B. Rangel presiding on Thursday over a hearing of the House Ways and Means Committee.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>Democrats believe that a long list of Republican lawmakers with legal troubles makes it impossible for Republicans to gain much ground on the issues of ethics and good government.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">House Committee on Ways and Means</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Democratic Party</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Kanjorski, Paul E</category>

    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Panel Proposes Broad Changes in Federal Financial Aid for College</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/education/19college.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/education/19college.html</guid>
      <description>The recommendations included a simpler application, Pell grant maximums linked to the consumer price index and federally financed college savings accounts for children in low-income families.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By TAMAR LEWIN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 07:09:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Colleges and Universities</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Finances</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Student Loans</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">College Board</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Chicago Unveils Multifaceted Plan to Curb Emissions of Heat-Trapping Gases</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19chicago.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19chicago.html</guid>
      <description>The blueprint would change the city’s building codes to promote energy efficiency, and it calls for installing huge solar panels at municipal properties and building alternative fueling stations.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By DIRK JOHNSON</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 07:18:44 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Chicago (Ill)</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Air Pollution</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Daley, Richard M</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Global Warming</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Energy Efficiency</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Office Buildings and Commercial Properties</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Vast Bailout by U.S. Proposed in Bid to Stem Financial Crisis</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/19fed.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/19fed.html</guid>

          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi answered questions Thursday after Congressional leaders met with Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson, left, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, right.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>Treasury and Fed officials were discussing with leaders in Congress a plan for the government to buy up distressed mortgages.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>

      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 13:34:02 GMT</pubDate>

    </item>
    <item>
      <title>A Bid to Curb Profit Gambit as Banks Fall</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/19backlash.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>

    <item>
      <title>Bush Emerges After Days of Financial Crisis</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/business/19bush.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>

          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>President Bush spoke about the economy at the White House on Thursday.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Doug Mills/The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>The president spoke briefly on Thursday after remaining largely out of sight as Wall Street has become engulfed by a financial crisis.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>

    <item>
      <title>The New McCain: More Aggressive and Scripted on the Campaign Trail</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19mccain.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19mccain.html</guid>

          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Senator John McCain at a rally on Thursday in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, with Gov. Sarah Palin.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Todd Heisler/The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>Senator John McCain’s once easygoing if irreverent campaign presence — endearing to crowds, though often resulting in gaffes — has been put out to pasture.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>

    <item>
      <title>Alaska Star May Add Luster to Tarnished Senator</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19stevens.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/politics/19stevens.html</guid>

        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/us/19stevens_75.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Gov. Sarah Palin, her husband, Todd, between them, joined Senator Ted Stevens in August at an appearance by President Bush.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Gerald Herbert/Associated Press</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>As Gov. Sarah Palin has moved to the national stage, Senator Ted Stevens, who goes on trial next week, has risen in some opinion polls in Alaska.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By WILLIAM YARDLEY</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 08:10:05 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Stevens, Ted</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Presidential Election of 2008</category>

    </item>
    <item>

    <item>
      <title>Bread Stays on Menu for Carp at Pennsylvania Lake</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19carp.html?partner=rssnyt&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/19/us/19carp.html</guid>
      <media:group>
        <media:content>
          <media:url>http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2008/09/19/us/19carp.75.jpg</media:url>
          <media:medium>image</media:medium>
          <media:height>75</media:height>
          <media:width>75</media:width>
        </media:content>
        <media:description>Tourists watch carp fight over bread that had been tossed into the Pymatuning Lake spillway.</media:description>
        <media:credit>Jeff Swensen for The New York Times</media:credit>
      </media:group>
      <description>Every year, an estimated 500,000 people trek to a lake to see a veritable carpet of carp, and the state has temporarily called off a plan to force people to stop feeding bread to the fish.<br/><br/><span class="advertisement"></span>
</description>
      <dc:creator>By SEAN D. HAMILL</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Sep 2008 08:11:38 GMT</pubDate>

    </item>
